title: AI Coding Training Program
description: Learn Python, programming fundamentals, and build beginner AI models.

days.content:
Objectives:
  • Understand variables, data types, and basic operators.
  • Learn control structures (if-else, loops).
  • Practice with simple Python programs.
Activities:
  • Interactive coding exercises.
  • Mini projects: Calculator, number guessing game.
Tools:
  • Google Colab or Jupyter Notebook

Objectives:
  • Learn about functions, lists, dictionaries, and tuples.
  • Use Python libraries like math, random, and datetime.
Activities:
  • Build a to-do list app.
  • Practice creating and calling functions.
Tools:
  • Python standard libraries

Objectives:
  • Understand what AI and ML are.
  • Learn types of ML: supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement learning.
  • Introduction to data, features, and labels.
Activities:
  • Class discussion on AI in daily life.
  • Basic ML demo using Scikit-learn (e.g., Iris dataset classification).
Tools:
  • Python, Scikit-learn, Pandas, Matplotlib

Objectives:
  • Learn about model training and evaluation.
  • Build and test a classification model using Scikit-learn.
  • Understand accuracy, precision, and confusion matrix.
Activities:
  • Hands-on: Train a model to classify handwritten digits (using sklearn.datasets.load_digits).
  • Visualizing results with plots.
Tools:
  • Python, Scikit-learn, Jupyter Notebook

Objectives:
  • Understand the basics of neural networks.
  • Build a simple neural network using TensorFlow/Keras.
  • Discuss AI ethics and responsible AI use.
Activities:
  • Train a simple neural net on MNIST dataset.
  • Group discussion or case study on AI and bias.
Tools:
  • Python, TensorFlow/Keras

title: Artificial Intelligence for Productivity
description: Use AI tools to enhance personal and professional productivity and automate workflows.

days.content: Introduction to AI and Productivity: Basics of AI, productivity tools, and identifying inefficiencies.
AI for Task and Time Management: Smart calendars, automation tools, and time blocking.
AI for Communication and Content: Writing tools, meeting AIs, and visual AI tools like Canva AI.
Data-Driven Productivity: AI in spreadsheets and dashboards with tools like Power BI and Excel Copilot.
Building AI Workflows & Future Skills: Create personal workflows and discuss AI ethics and future skills.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Marketing and Branding
description: Apply AI in marketing strategies, content creation, SEO, and branding.

days.content: AI in Marketing & Branding: ML, NLP in marketing, ethics and customer behavior.
Consumer Insights & Personalization: Segmentation, sentiment analysis, and personalized strategies.
Content Marketing and Branding: AI-generated content, visual creation, and brand persona building.
Advertising, SEO & Campaign Optimization: AI in ad platforms, SEO, and campaign tracking.
AI-Powered Brand Strategy: Strategic planning, reputation management, and trend forecasting.

title: Artificial Intelligence Writing Tools - Training Program
description: Learn to use AI tools for writing, editing, SEO, and content creation while maintaining ethical standards.

days.content:
Objective: Understand the basics of AI and its role in the writing process.
Topics Covered:
  • What is AI? A brief overview
  • How AI is transforming the writing industry
  • Types of AI writing tools (generative, assistive, editing, summarization)
  • Ethical concerns and limitations
Activities:
  • Group discussion: “Can AI replace human writers?”
  • Quick demo: ChatGPT, Grammarly, and Quillbot
Assignment:
  • Write a short piece (150–200 words) manually and compare it with an AI-generated version.

Objective: Gain hands-on experience with leading AI writing tools.
Topics Covered:
  • Deep dive into ChatGPT, Jasper, Writesonic, Copy.ai, Grammarly, Quillbot
  • Tool comparison: strengths and weaknesses
  • Free vs paid versions – what do you really need?
Activities:
  • Guided exploration of at least three tools
  • Case study: Using AI for marketing content
Assignment:
  • Create a blog post outline using three different tools and compare the results.

Objective: Learn to co-write and edit content effectively using AI.
Topics Covered:
  • Prompt engineering basics
  • Co-writing techniques with AI
  • Editing and enhancing content using AI
  • Avoiding overreliance and plagiarism
Activities:
  • Live demo: Writing a blog post with ChatGPT
  • AI-assisted headline generation exercise
Assignment:
  • Co-write a 500-word article using AI and polish it with Grammarly or Hemingway Editor.

Objective: Apply AI tools for specific writing needs.
Topics Covered:
  • AI for academic writing (summarizing, citation help)
  • AI for social media content
  • AI for SEO and keyword optimization
  • Translation and paraphrasing tools
Activities:
  • SEO optimization challenge using AI
  • Create a week’s worth of AI-generated social media posts
Assignment:
  • Use an AI tool to generate and optimize a product description or academic abstract.

Objective: Learn how to sustainably integrate AI tools into your workflow.
Topics Covered:
  • Building your AI writing toolkit
  • Workflow integration (Notion, Google Docs, CMS platforms)
  • Ethical writing with AI: Transparency, authorship, and data privacy
  • The future of AI in creative and professional writing
Activities:
  • Panel or guest talk (if available): AI + Creativity
  • Create your AI writing workflow diagram

title: How to Build a Very Basic Web Page
description: Learn how to create, style, and publish your first web page using HTML and CSS.

days.content:
Topics:
  • What is a website? What is a web page?
  • Introduction to HTML
  • Basic structure of an HTML document (<html>, <head>, <body>)
  • Common HTML tags: <h1>–<h6>, <p>, <a>, <img>, <ul>, <ol>, <li>, <br>, <hr>
Activities:
  • Write your first “Hello, World!” page
  • Add headings and paragraphs
  • Insert an image and a hyperlink
Outcome: Create a simple HTML page with text, an image, and a working link.

Topics:
  • Using <div> and semantic tags (<header>, <nav>, <main>, <footer>)
  • Inserting images with alt text
  • Lists and links (internal and external)
  • File and folder structure for web projects
Activities:
  • Create a simple web page layout using divs
  • Add navigation links to different sections of the same page
Outcome: Build a basic, well-structured HTML layout for a webpage.

Topics:
  • What is CSS and how it works with HTML
  • Inline, internal, and external CSS
  • Basic CSS properties: color, background, font, border, margin, padding
Activities:
  • Add internal CSS to style headings, text, and background
  • Experiment with fonts and colors
Outcome: Style a basic webpage using internal CSS.

Topics:
  • Box model (margin, border, padding, content)
  • CSS display properties
  • Aligning elements using flexbox (introduction)
  • Responsive basics (viewport tag, relative units)
Activities:
  • Create a simple layout using flexbox or float
  • Adjust layout spacing with the box model
Outcome: Build a simple, styled layout with organized content.

Topics:
  • Review of HTML and CSS learned so far
  • Building a final mini-project (personal webpage or portfolio)
  • Introduction to publishing with GitHub Pages (or alternatives)
Activities:
  • Build your personal webpage with sections: About Me, Hobbies, Contact
  • Upload to GitHub and publish it online
Outcome: Complete and publish your very first live webpage.

title: Circular Economy Fundamentals – Theoretical Foundations and Local Perspectives
description: Explore the theoretical models and local strategies for implementing circular economy practices in real-world settings.

days.content:
Theme: From Linear to Circular – Why Change is Needed
Objectives:
  • Understand environmental, economic, and social motivations for the circular economy.
  • Explore the historical evolution and basic concepts of the circular economy.
Topics:
  • Linear vs Circular Economy
  • Systems thinking and sustainability
  • Circular economy benefits and drivers
  • Key global frameworks (e.g., Ellen MacArthur Foundation, UN SDGs)
Activities:
  • Group discussion: “Where are we now?”
  • Interactive mapping: “Waste in our daily lives”
  • Video case study: “Story of Stuff”

Theme: Building Blocks of Circularity
Objectives:
  • Examine theoretical underpinnings and models of circular economy.
  • Introduce design thinking and life cycle approaches.
Topics:
  • Cradle-to-Cradle, Performance Economy, Industrial Symbiosis
  • 9R Framework (Refuse, Rethink, Reduce…)
  • Biomimicry and regenerative design
  • Circular business models (Product-as-a-Service, Sharing economy)
Activities:
  • Workshop: Redesigning a common product using circular principles
  • Guest speaker: Circular economy researcher or practitioner

Theme: Enabling Circular Economies through Governance
Objectives:
  • Analyze international and national policies supporting circularity.
  • Understand the role of regulations, incentives, and measurement tools.
Topics:
  • EU Circular Economy Action Plan
  • ISO standards (e.g., ISO 59004, 14040)
  • National/local policy landscapes
  • Circular economy metrics and indicators
Activities:
  • Policy mapping activity
  • Debate: “Should circularity be mandated or incentivized?”

Theme: Circular Economy in Practice – Local Realities
Objectives:
  • Explore how circular economy can be implemented in local contexts.
  • Identify community-based innovations and grassroots movements.
Topics:
  • Urban circularity (waste, energy, mobility)
  • Rural/regional perspectives
  • Local circular business initiatives
  • Social dimensions and stakeholder engagement
Activities:
  • Field visit or virtual tour of a local circular initiative
  • Group task: Circular mapping of participants’ own city/town
  • Panel discussion: Local entrepreneurs, NGOs, policy makers

Theme: Designing the Circular Transition
Objectives:
  • Synthesize learnings to co-create localized circular economy strategies.
  • Develop action plans for implementation in participants’ sectors or regions.
Topics:
  • Circular transition strategies
  • Tools for change management
  • Communication and behavior change
Activities:
  • Co-creation lab: Develop a local circular economy roadmap
  • Group presentations
  • Feedback and reflection session
  • Certificates and closing ceremony

title: Creative Applications of Artificial Intelligence
description: Discover how AI is transforming creativity across visual arts, music, writing, and storytelling—and build your own AI-powered creative project.

days.content:
Theme: Understanding Creativity + AI Capabilities
Topics:
  • What is creativity? Can AI be creative?
  • Overview of creative AI applications
  • Introduction to generative AI (GPT, DALL·E, Midjourney, etc.)
  • Live demo: Creating stories and poems with AI
Hands-on:
  • Use ChatGPT or similar tools to generate short creative content (e.g., poems, jokes, dialogue scenes)
Outcome: Participants recognize AI's role in augmenting human creativity and start experimenting with prompts.

Theme: Exploring AI-Generated Images, Design & Style Transfer
Topics:
  • How AI generates images (GANs, diffusion models)
  • Applications in fashion, product design, and marketing
  • Style transfer and image-to-image translation
  • Tools: DALL·E, Runway ML, DeepArt, Midjourney
Hands-on:
  • Create AI-generated artwork and posters using image generation tools
  • Try AI-assisted design with Canva and other tools
Outcome: Participants produce visual art using AI and understand its design applications.

Theme: Audio Generation and Music Composition
Topics:
  • How AI composes music (RNNs, Transformers for music)
  • Tools: AIVA, Amper, Soundraw, Google's Magenta
  • Real-world use: AI in film scoring, advertising, and video games
Hands-on:
  • Compose a short soundtrack using AI tools
  • Experiment with voice cloning and text-to-speech
Outcome: Participants create AI-generated music and understand the creative workflow.

Theme: Narrative Creation, Games, and Interactivity
Topics:
  • Natural Language Generation (NLG) for storytelling
  • AI in game design and interactive narratives
  • Chatbots as characters in games or experiences
Hands-on:
  • Write a short story or interactive fiction with GPT
  • Prototype a simple AI-driven text-based game or chatbot
Outcome: Participants explore how AI can enhance narrative design and interactivity.

Theme: Bringing It All Together + Critical Reflection
Topics:
  • Final project development (individually or in small groups)
  • Presentations and feedback
  • Ethical concerns: authenticity, authorship, bias, and impact on creative jobs
  • Future trends in creative AI
Hands-on:
  • Develop a creative AI project (e.g., AI comic strip, music video, digital poem)
  • Peer review and idea sharing
Outcome: Participants present a small creative AI concept or prototype and engage in reflective discussion.

title: Digital Storytelling for Active Citizenship
description: Empower communities and drive change through multimedia storytelling focused on civic engagement, ethics, and social impact.

days.content:
Morning Session:
  • Introduction to Active Citizenship: Definition and significance
  • Case studies of digital storytelling for civic engagement
  • What is digital storytelling?
  • Types of digital stories: narrative, advocacy, documentary
Afternoon Session:
  • Overview of tools (e.g., Canva, Adobe Spark, iMovie, Audacity)
  • Hands-on activity: create a basic digital intro using text and images
  • Discussion & Reflection: How digital stories shape perspectives and promote change

Morning Session:
  • Community mapping and issue selection
  • Group brainstorming on relevant social topics
  • Story structure basics and creating a storyboard
Afternoon Session:
  • Writing scripts, collecting media (photos, sounds, videos)
  • Peer feedback on storyboards and drafts

Morning Session:
  • Intro to video/audio/image editing tools
  • Multimedia integration tips
  • Tips for mobile recording, lighting, and sound
Afternoon Session:
  • Basic editing techniques: transitions, pacing, subtitles
  • Start assembling the draft story

Morning Session:
  • Ethics in Digital Storytelling: Consent, privacy, representation
  • Avoiding harm and bias in storytelling
  • Digital Citizenship: Being responsible online and using platforms for civic engagement
Afternoon Session:
  • Story presentations and group critiques
  • Aligning stories with citizenship goals

Morning Session:
  • Polishing edits, adding effects, subtitles
  • Creating a compelling title and summary
  • How to publish and promote on social media
  • Using hashtags and building audience engagement
Afternoon Session:
  • Final screening of digital stories
  • Group reflection and takeaways

title: Digital Pedagogy and Innovation - 5-Day Training Program
description: Explore how to design, implement, assess, and innovate with digital tools and pedagogical strategies in modern education.

days.content:
Morning Session:
  • What is digital pedagogy?
  • The evolution of education with technology
  • Key principles and models of digital pedagogy
  • How technology impacts teaching and learning
  • Understanding the digital divide and ensuring equity in digital education
Afternoon Session:
  • Current trends in digital learning and innovation
  • The role of multimedia, gamification, and interactive technologies in pedagogy
  • Case studies: Successful examples of digital pedagogy in practice

Morning Session:
  • Understanding the basics of instructional design
  • Strategies for creating engaging and interactive learning environments
  • Overview of digital tools and platforms for content delivery
  • Tools for multimedia creation, collaboration, and communication
Afternoon Session:
  • Hands-on: Designing a digital lesson using appropriate tools
  • Group activity: Creating a collaborative online learning activity

Morning Session:
  • What is active learning, and why is it important?
  • Facilitating active learning in digital and blended environments
  • Introduction to collaborative tools
  • Using virtual classrooms for engagement and peer interaction
Afternoon Session:
  • Hands-on: Using H5P, Nearpod, and Kahoot to create interactive lessons
  • Strategies for encouraging participation and collaboration online

Morning Session:
  • Formative and summative assessments in digital environments
  • Exploring digital assessment tools and platforms
  • Best practices for online testing and assignments
  • Ensuring academic integrity in digital assessments
Afternoon Session:
  • Providing constructive feedback digitally
  • Evaluating the effectiveness of digital learning tools and resources

Morning Session:
  • Exploring AI, VR, AR, and emerging tech in education
  • Integrating these technologies into teaching
  • Innovative pedagogical models and case studies
  • Discussion on future trends in digital education
Afternoon Session:
  • Create a personalized digital pedagogy plan
  • Group discussion and peer feedback
  • Final Q&A and feedback session
  • Awarding certificates of completion

title: Digital Tools for Creative and Secure Education
description: Learn to design engaging, multimedia-rich lessons while maintaining a safe digital environment for learners and educators.

days.content:
Theme: Exploring creativity in a digital classroom
Learning Outcomes:
  • Understand the role of digital tools in fostering creativity
  • Identify types of tools that support creative teaching and learning
Topics:
  • Overview of creative pedagogy in the digital age
  • Introduction to tools like Canva, Padlet, Genially, and Jamboard
  • Brainstorming activity: "What does a creative classroom look like?"
Activities:
  • Hands-on with Canva: create an interactive class poster
  • Group discussion and reflection

Theme: Engaging students with multimedia
Learning Outcomes:
  • Create interactive lessons using digital platforms
  • Integrate multimedia into educational content effectively
Topics:
  • Tools for video creation (Loom, Flip, Adobe Express)
  • Interactive presentations with Genially and Nearpod
  • Audio tools (Vocaroo, Audacity basics)
Activities:
  • Create a short interactive lesson with multimedia tools
  • Peer review of created content

Theme: Fostering collaboration in digital environments
Learning Outcomes:
  • Utilize collaborative platforms to enhance student engagement
  • Facilitate teamwork and communication with digital tools
Topics:
  • Google Workspace for Education (Docs, Slides, Forms, Jamboard)
  • Microsoft Teams / OneNote in education
  • Real-time feedback and student participation tools (Kahoot, Mentimeter)
Activities:
  • Group project using Google Slides and Forms
  • Simulate a virtual collaborative classroom scenario

Theme: Protecting learners and educators online
Learning Outcomes:
  • Understand basic cybersecurity principles relevant to education
  • Apply best practices to maintain digital safety
Topics:
  • Password hygiene, phishing awareness, privacy settings
  • Secure communication and data storage
  • Safe browsing and digital footprint
Activities:
  • Cybersecurity quiz and threat simulations
  • Discussion: "What does digital safety mean for students?"

Theme: Putting it all together
Learning Outcomes:
  • Design a lesson plan integrating secure and creative digital tools
  • Reflect on the impact of digital tools in personal teaching practice
Topics:
  • Lesson planning with integrated tools
  • Evaluation criteria for choosing safe and creative tools
  • Resources for ongoing professional development
Activities:
  • Create and present a lesson plan or mini-project
  • Peer feedback and group reflection
  • Certificate distribution & Q&A

title: Digital Transformation in Inclusive Classrooms
description: Learn to design equitable and accessible digital learning experiences that meet the needs of all students in diverse and inclusive classrooms.

days.content:
Learning Objectives:
  • Define inclusive education and its importance
  • Understand the concept of digital transformation in education
  • Explore global trends and frameworks (e.g., UDL - Universal Design for Learning)
Activities:
  • Icebreaker: Diversity Bingo
  • Keynote: 'Why Digital Inclusion Matters'
  • Group Discussion: Barriers to inclusion in current classrooms
  • Interactive Presentation: UDL principles and digital education

Learning Objectives:
  • Explore various assistive technologies (AT) for students with disabilities
  • Evaluate digital tools for visual, auditory, cognitive, and mobility support
  • Understand how to make digital content accessible (WCAG guidelines)
Activities:
  • Demo: Screen readers, text-to-speech tools, and captioning
  • Hands-on Workshop: Creating accessible documents and presentations
  • Case Study: Successful use of AT in inclusive classrooms

Learning Objectives:
  • Use digital platforms (e.g., Google Classroom, Microsoft Teams) to support diverse learners
  • Design interactive and engaging inclusive lessons
  • Differentiate instruction using technology
Activities:
  • Group Activity: Redesign a traditional lesson into an inclusive digital format
  • Tool Exploration: Edpuzzle, Flip, Canva for Education
  • Peer Review: Share and critique lesson plans

Learning Objectives:
  • Understand cultural responsiveness in digital education
  • Promote equity through technology in multilingual and diverse classrooms
  • Address the digital divide and promote digital citizenship
Activities:
  • Panel Talk: Voices from diverse classrooms
  • Activity: Inclusive storytelling using digital tools
  • Reflection Exercise: Assessing biases in digital content

Learning Objectives:
  • Develop a personalized action plan for digital inclusion
  • Identify key stakeholders and resources
  • Evaluate and reflect on professional growth
Activities:
  • Group Presentations: Action plans for digital inclusion
  • Feedback Session: Peer and facilitator review
  • Wrap-up: Certification & digital badge ceremony

title: Empowering Teachers with STEM and Coding Skills
description: Equip teachers with the skills and tools to integrate STEM and beginner-friendly coding into their teaching practice.

days.content:
Objective: Build awareness of STEM and its relevance in modern education.
Topics:
  • What is STEM? Why is it important?
  • The role of teachers in STEM advocacy
  • Real-world examples and case studies
  • Introduction to 21st-century skills (collaboration, critical thinking, creativity, communication)
Activities:
  • Icebreaker: STEM Around You
  • Group discussion: Challenges and opportunities in current classrooms
  • STEM scavenger hunt (virtual or physical)
Outcomes:
  • Understand the value of STEM
  • Identify current STEM applications in daily life and curriculum

Objective: Equip teachers with tools to integrate STEM across subjects.
Topics:
  • STEM instructional strategies
  • Inquiry-based and project-based learning
  • Cross-disciplinary lesson planning
  • Aligning with curriculum standards
Activities:
  • Design a mini cross-curricular STEM activity
  • Case study analysis
  • Group brainstorming: “STEMifying” your subject
Outcomes:
  • Develop strategies for cross-curricular STEM learning
  • Create a draft of a subject-specific STEM lesson

Objective: Introduce basic coding concepts using beginner-friendly platforms.
Topics:
  • What is coding and computational thinking?
  • Block-based programming with Scratch
  • Introduction to logic: sequences, loops, conditionals
  • Classroom-friendly platforms (Scratch, Tynker, Code.org)
Activities:
  • Hands-on Scratch workshop (create a simple animation or quiz)
  • Pair programming
  • Reflective journaling: How can I use this in my classroom?
Outcomes:
  • Understand basic coding concepts
  • Build and modify a simple Scratch project

Objective: Use coding to enhance STEM education through real projects.
Topics:
  • Connecting coding to science and math
  • Intro to micro:bit (or similar hardware, optional)
  • STEM and coding project design
Activities:
  • Choose and build a STEM + coding mini project (e.g., a weather station, quiz app, interactive story)
  • Gallery walk and peer feedback
  • Troubleshooting and debugging session
Outcomes:
  • Build an integrated STEM-coding project
  • Gain confidence in troubleshooting and facilitating coding activities

Objective: Plan how to implement STEM and coding in the classroom sustainably.
Topics:
  • Assessing STEM and coding skills
  • Reflective practice and continuous learning
  • Resources and communities of practice
  • Action planning for your school/classroom
Activities:
  • Present final mini-projects
  • Create a personal 3-month action plan
  • Feedback circle and training wrap-up
Outcomes:
  • Develop an implementation plan for STEM and coding
  • Share and receive feedback on projects and ideas

title: Gamified Learning – Circular Economy in Action
description: Learn Circular Economy concepts through interactive games, simulations, and creative challenges that encourage teamwork and sustainability thinking.

days.content:
Theme: From Linear to Circular
Objectives:
  • Understand the basics of Circular Economy (CE)
  • Explore gamification as a learning tool
Activities:
  • Icebreaker game: “Linear vs Circular” – sort processes into linear or circular models
  • Mini-lecture: CE principles (Design Out Waste, Keep Materials in Use, Regenerate Natural Systems)
  • Interactive quiz (e.g., Kahoot) on CE basics
  • Group challenge: Visual “before & after” of a linear product lifecycle turning circular

Theme: Rethink Waste
Objectives:
  • Learn about waste hierarchy and resource loops
  • Explore CE strategies like recycling, upcycling, and closed loops
Activities:
  • Simulation game: “Circular City” – redesign a city for minimal waste and maximum reuse
  • Case study escape room: Solve clues using circular principles
  • Creative challenge: Design a product using only “waste” materials

Theme: See the Big Picture
Objectives:
  • Understand systems thinking in CE
  • Explore innovative business models (PaaS, leasing, sharing platforms)
Activities:
  • Gamified workshop: Circular business model canvas game
  • Role-play marketplace: Teams pitch circular business ideas
  • Simulation board game: Manage circular supply chains and compete on KPIs

Theme: CE in Action
Objectives:
  • Explore real-world CE applications in industries
  • Identify barriers and enablers of CE
Activities:
  • Virtual field trip or guest speaker from CE company
  • Strategy game: “Fix the Supply Chain!” – redesign a company model
  • Workshop: Create a CE action plan for own organization/community

Theme: Be the Change
Objectives:
  • Apply CE knowledge in a creative challenge
  • Reflect and plan next steps
Activities:
  • Circular Game Jam: Create a mini board/digital game to teach CE
  • Presentations & peer voting
  • Reflection circle: Personal takeaways & next steps
  • Feedback collection & certification

title: Inclusive Education and Adaptive Learning Strategies
description: Gain practical strategies and tools to support diverse learners and create inclusive, accessible, and collaborative classrooms.

title: 5-Day Training Program: Information Technologies
description: Build foundational IT knowledge, develop digital literacy, and explore practical skills in networks, software, cybersecurity, and emerging technologies.

days.content:
Topics Covered:
  • What is Information Technology?
  • History & evolution of IT
  • Types of computer systems (desktop, laptop, mobile)
  • Basic hardware components: CPU, RAM, storage, peripherals
  • Operating systems overview (Windows, macOS, Linux)
Activities:
  • Computer components matching activity
  • Operating system navigation basics
Outcome: Learners can identify computer components and navigate an OS.

Topics Covered:
  • Types of software: system vs. application
  • Microsoft Office / Google Workspace overview
  • Word processing basics
  • Spreadsheet fundamentals (formulas, charts)
  • Creating presentations
Activities:
  • Create a formatted document
  • Build a simple budget spreadsheet
  • Make a 3-slide presentation
Outcome: Learners can use basic productivity tools for common tasks.

Topics Covered:
  • What is a network? LAN, WAN, the Internet
  • Network devices: routers, switches, modems
  • IP address, DNS, and how the web works
  • Email, web browsing, and cloud storage
  • Digital communication tools (Zoom, Teams)
Activities:
  • Draw a home/office network diagram
  • Set up and troubleshoot a basic Wi-Fi connection
Outcome: Learners understand how computers communicate and use internet tools effectively.

Topics Covered:
  • Types of threats: viruses, phishing, malware
  • Password management and two-factor authentication
  • Safe browsing practices
  • Data backup and recovery
  • Introduction to firewalls and antivirus software
Activities:
  • Spot the phishing email game
  • Set up a secure password vault
Outcome: Learners can protect their data and recognize common security risks.

Topics Covered:
  • IT support roles & troubleshooting basics
  • Cloud computing, AI, IoT, and Big Data (intro)
  • Trends in IT careers and certifications
  • Responsible use of technology & digital citizenship
Activities:
  • Simulate an IT helpdesk scenario
  • Group discussion: How tech is changing the world
Outcome: Learners are aware of real-world IT applications and career opportunities.

title: Innovative Digital Tools for Interactive Learning
description: Discover and apply cutting-edge digital tools to design interactive, collaborative, and tech-enhanced learning experiences.

days.content:
Theme: Setting the Stage for Innovation
Objectives:
  • Understand the principles of interactive learning
  • Explore the current landscape of digital learning tools
Tools/Topics Introduced:
  • Constructivism, active learning
  • Digital tool categories: content creation, collaboration, assessment, gamification
  • Platforms: Google Workspace, Microsoft 365, Canva, Padlet
Activities:
  • Icebreaker: Mentimeter or Slido poll
  • Group discussion: What makes learning interactive?
  • Tool carousel exploration
Homework/Reflection: Reflective journal on current digital tool use and growth areas

Theme: Making Learning Visually and Intellectually Stimulating
Objectives:
  • Create engaging instructional content
  • Use visual storytelling and multimedia tools
Tools/Topics Introduced:
  • Canva for Education, Prezi, Genially, Adobe Express, Book Creator
Activities:
  • Mini-project: Redesign a lesson using a digital tool
  • Peer feedback session
Homework/Reflection: Finalize one digital content item for portfolio

Theme: Connecting Learners and Building Communities
Objectives:
  • Foster collaboration via digital platforms
  • Enable real-time and asynchronous communication
Tools/Topics Introduced:
  • Padlet, Jamboard, Miro, Google Docs, OneNote, Flip
Activities:
  • Scenario challenge: Design collaborative activity using 2 tools
  • Live demo: Brainstorming in Miro/Jamboard
Homework/Reflection: Create collaborative activity outline for your context

Theme: Making Learning Measurable and Fun
Objectives:
  • Use tools for formative and summative assessment
  • Integrate gamification for engagement
Tools/Topics Introduced:
  • Kahoot, Quizizz, Socrative, Formative, Edpuzzle, Classcraft
Activities:
  • Gamified quiz battle
  • Create self-graded formative quiz with feedback
Homework/Reflection: Develop short digital assessment or gamified review

Theme: Bringing It All Together
Objectives:
  • Design cohesive digitally-integrated lessons
  • Reflect on learning and set implementation goals
Activities:
  • Capstone: Design mini-lesson using 2–3 tools
  • Gallery walk and peer feedback
  • 30-day action plan development
  • Group reflection (Flip or Padlet)
  • Digital certificate ceremony

title: Media Literacy and Digital Citizenship Education
description: Empower participants to think critically about media, act responsibly online, and teach or advocate for digital citizenship and literacy.

days.content:
Objective: Build foundational understanding of key concepts and frameworks.
Topics:
  • What is Media Literacy?
  • Understanding Digital Citizenship
  • The role of media in society
  • Media consumption trends
Activities:
  • Icebreaker: “My digital day” reflection
  • Group discussion: How media impacts our views
  • Short video: Overview of media evolution
  • Concept map creation (collaborative)
Learning Outcome: Participants can define media literacy and digital citizenship and identify their relevance in daily life.

Objective: Equip learners with tools to critically analyze media messages.
Topics:
  • Identifying bias, stereotypes, and agendas
  • Spotting misinformation and fake news
  • Evaluating sources for credibility and reliability
  • Algorithms and filter bubbles
Activities:
  • Media comparison: reporting same event from different sources
  • Fact-checking exercise (Snopes, FactCheck.org)
  • Discussion: Personal experiences with misinformation
Learning Outcome: Participants can critically analyze media for bias, credibility, and misinformation.

Objective: Foster awareness of digital privacy and responsible use of technology.
Topics:
  • What is a digital footprint?
  • Online privacy & security
  • Cyberbullying, trolling, and online harassment
  • Managing online identities
Activities:
  • Privacy settings walkthrough
  • Scenarios: Responding to digital dilemmas
  • Digital footprint audit
Learning Outcome: Participants can explain online risks and take steps to protect their privacy and digital identity.

Objective: Encourage ethical and respectful digital participation.
Topics:
  • Digital etiquette and netiquette
  • Empathy in online communication
  • Intellectual property and digital plagiarism
  • Civic engagement in the digital age
Activities:
  • Case study: Online debates and respectful discourse
  • Role-play: Ethical decisions in digital spaces
  • Group brainstorm: What does a responsible digital citizen look like?
Learning Outcome: Participants can demonstrate ethical behavior and empathy in digital interactions.

Objective: Help participants integrate knowledge into personal, educational, or professional settings.
Topics:
  • Designing a digital citizenship lesson (for educators)
  • Creating awareness campaigns (for communities or youth)
  • Policies and resources to support media literacy
Activities:
  • Project presentations (lesson plan, campaign, or toolkit)
  • Peer feedback
  • Final reflection and action planning
Learning Outcome: Participants can apply their learning to real-life contexts and advocate for digital responsibility.

title: Soft Skills Development with Artificial Intelligence
description: Enhance communication, emotional intelligence, collaboration, and critical thinking using AI-supported tools and personalized development strategies.

days.content:
Objectives:
  • Define soft skills and their relevance
  • Introduce how AI can support soft skill growth
Sessions:
  • Ice-breaker: Soft Skills in Real Life
  • Key Soft Skills for the 21st Century
  • AI Overview: Capabilities & Trends in Human Development
  • Tools Demo: ChatGPT, Grammarly, Replika, Crystal
Activities:
  • Self-assessment survey (Google Forms or AI-based tests)
  • Group Discussion: “Can AI Teach Empathy?”
Outcome: Participants will articulate the value of soft skills and identify AI tools that assist with soft skill enhancement.

Objectives:
  • Improve verbal and written communication using AI tools
Sessions:
  • Communication Basics: Clarity, Tone, and Listening
  • AI-Powered Writing Assistants (Grammarly, ChatGPT, Wordtune)
  • Practicing Active Listening & Feedback with AI bots
Activities:
  • Rewrite emails/messages for tone and clarity using AI
  • Simulated conversations with Replika or ChatGPT
Outcome: Participants will demonstrate improved communication through AI-assisted tools and receive AI-generated feedback.

Objectives:
  • Understand and develop emotional intelligence using AI simulations
Sessions:
  • What is Emotional Intelligence? The 5 Domains
  • AI for Self-Awareness: Sentiment Analysis, Mood Tracking
  • Empathy in Action: Simulated Conversations with Virtual Characters
Activities:
  • Use mood tracking apps (Moodfit, Youper)
  • AI-driven role-play: Responding to emotional cues
Outcome: Participants will show enhanced self-awareness and empathetic response patterns through AI feedback and practice.

Objectives:
  • Enhance teamwork and conflict resolution with AI-assisted tools
Sessions:
  • Collaboration and Conflict: Soft Skill Pillars
  • AI in Team Dynamics: DISC Profiles, CrystalKnows
  • Simulated Scenarios: Difficult Conversations & Feedback Delivery
Activities:
  • Group challenge using Miro or Jamboard + ChatGPT
  • AI-generated feedback roleplay
Outcome: Participants will apply collaborative and conflict resolution strategies in team simulations with AI support.

Objectives:
  • Sharpen critical thinking and prepare a growth plan with AI
Sessions:
  • Critical Thinking Frameworks (6 Thinking Hats, STAR Method)
  • Using AI for Idea Generation and Perspective Shifting
  • Building a Personal AI-Enhanced Soft Skills Development Plan
Activities:
  • AI brainstorm: Solve a case using ChatGPT or Ideaflip
  • Create a development roadmap using Notion, Trello, or AI coaches
Outcome: Participants will leave with a clear, actionable plan for continued soft skills improvement using AI tools.

title: Sustainability in Education & Green Skills
description: Equip educators with the knowledge and tools to integrate sustainability into curricula, promote eco-conscious practices, and foster green skills for future careers.

days.content:
Morning Session:
  • Definition, history, and principles of sustainability (environmental, economic, and social pillars)
  • The role of education in promoting sustainability
  • What are green skills? Types (technical and practical)
  • Relevance in modern careers
  • Introduction to green sectors: renewable energy, sustainable agriculture, green tech
Afternoon Session:
  • Integration into educational policies and strategies
  • UN Sustainable Development Goals and education
  • Case studies of successful examples

Morning Session:
  • Designing sustainability-focused curricula
  • Resources and tools for integration
  • Cross-disciplinary teaching methods
Afternoon Session:
  • Group workshop: Redesign a lesson plan with sustainability themes
  • Peer presentations and feedback

Morning Session:
  • Impact of green industries on the job market
  • Key green skills by sector (renewable energy, agriculture, etc.)
Afternoon Session:
  • Practical teaching methods and activities
  • Enhancing student employability through green skills

Morning Session:
  • Sustainable buildings and energy management
  • Waste and water reduction strategies
  • Examples of green campuses
Afternoon Session:
  • Action Plan Workshop: Draft institutional sustainability plans
  • Focus areas: energy, waste, sourcing

Morning Session:
  • Evaluation tools and KPIs
  • Case study: Measuring success in sustainability initiatives
Afternoon Session:
  • Strategies to build eco-conscious behaviors
  • Leadership and advocacy in sustainability
  • Final task: Design a sustainability awareness campaign
  • Summary of key learnings and certificate ceremony

title: Visual Creativity with Artificial Intelligence - Training Program
description: Explore AI-powered tools and methods to create, enhance, and evaluate digital art, design, and creative visuals while gaining hands-on experience through collaborative projects.

days.content:
Session 1: AI Fundamentals and Visual Creativity
  • What is AI? Overview of machine learning, deep learning, and neural networks
  • AI’s role in creative industries: art, design, animation
  • Case studies: AI-generated paintings and digital designs
Session 2: Overview of AI Technologies for Visual Creation
  • GANs, Style Transfer, Image Synthesis
  • Tools: DeepArt, DALL·E, RunwayML
Hands-on Activity: Use tools like DeepArt to transform images into art using AI.

Session 1: GANs and Neural Networks
  • Deep dive into GANs and their function in visual art
  • Learning from existing artwork
  • Supervised vs. unsupervised vs. reinforcement learning
Session 2: AI in Digital Art and Design
  • AI for photo enhancement and digital painting
  • Tools: Adobe Sensei, Canva AI
Hands-on Activity: Generate images using DALL·E or GAN-based tools with custom prompts.

Session 1: AI Image Generation and Customization
  • Explore tools like DALL·E, MidJourney, Artbreeder
  • Customize AI-generated visuals
Session 2: Style Transfer and AI Filters
  • Apply artistic styles to images
  • Use AI filters and enhancements
Hands-on Activity: Design a project using AI-generated visuals with applied filters.

Session 1: AI and Motion Graphics/Video Design
  • AI for video effects, animation, and VFX
  • AI in film: from script to visual
Session 2: AI for Branding and Marketing Design
  • Create logos, social media graphics, and promotional visuals
  • Boost branding with AI-generated design
Hands-on Activity: Create an animation or marketing video using RunwayML or Synthesia.

Session 1: Ethical and Aesthetic Considerations
  • Copyright & ownership in AI art
  • Human creativity vs. AI generation
  • AI's future in visual creativity
Session 2: Collaborative AI Projects
  • Group creation of AI-based visuals or design challenges
  • Project presentation & peer critique
Hands-on Activity: Final project using AI tools to create original visual content, presented with creative reflection.
